reasoning: I analyzed each example carefully, noting where the feature activation occurred and what genomic elements were present at those locations. I looked for patterns in the activation spikes across different organisms, examining the genomic context of each activation site. I identified that activation consistently occurred at or near transposase genes and mobile genetic elements across diverse bacterial species.
findings: Across multiple examples, the feature shows sharp activation spikes specifically associated with transposase genes and insertion sequence (IS) elements. In section_1, activation occurs at tnpB (IS66 family insertion sequence element accessory protein). In section_4, activation appears at both a Tis1421-transposase and an IS5 family transposase. In section_7, the feature activates near an IS256 family transposase. This pattern occurs across phylogenetically diverse bacteria, suggesting the feature detects a conserved sequence or structural motif specific to mobile genetic elements.
conclusion: This feature reliably detects transposase genes and insertion sequences across diverse bacterial genomes, representing a biologically meaningful pattern associated with mobile genetic elements.
title: Bacterial Transposase/IS Element Detector
description: This feature specifically detects transposase genes and insertion sequence (IS) elements in bacterial genomes. It shows sharp, localized activation spikes at or near genes encoding various transposase families (IS66, IS5, IS256) across phylogenetically diverse bacteria. The activation pattern is highly consistent, suggesting the feature recognizes a conserved sequence or structural motif characteristic of bacterial mobile genetic elements. This detection capability is significant as transposases are key drivers of bacterial genome plasticity and horizontal gene transfer. The feature works across diverse bacterial phyla, from Proteobacteria to Gram-positive bacteria, demonstrating its broad taxonomic applicability.
